Pre-Game Insights: Bosnia and Herzegovina and Hungary aim for their first 2024-25 UEFA Nations League victory in Monday’s clash in Zenica.
Neither side has managed to secure a win in this campaign, and with relegation looming, emotions are running high.
Both squads have shown flashes of quality in their recent games, but inconsistency and defensive frailties have left them vulnerable.
Experts predict a tightly contested affair where nerves and strategy will play a significant role.
Bosnia have lost eight of their last nine international games, yet their only draw in this period came against Hungary in a 0-0 result just last month.
Hungary come into this fixture off the back of consecutive draws, including a 1-1 draw against the Netherlands despite playing against ten men.
Bosnia’s defensive issues are highlighted by conceding seven goals in just three Nations League matches.
Edin Dzeko has scored in two of his last three outings for Bosnia.
Hungary’s Roland Sallai remains a threat, evidenced by his 18th international goal against the Netherlands.
Dominik Szoboszlai’s creativity will be essential for Hungary, though he might struggle if the team continues to falter in front of goal.
